text: micro Finance for the last decade and a
half or so has really been hailed as the
Panacea for the poor and the fact is
that especially in areas like southeast
Asia in particular micro Finance has
helped hundreds of millions of people uh
climb out of poverty they have not NE
necessarily gone from poverty to wealth
not from poverty to True Prosperity but
they certainly have gotten out of the
most abject sides of poverty now one of
the dirty little secrets behind micr
Finance is that the loans are actually
quite expensive um the average rate
globally is about 35 to 40% and I don't
know about you but I would have a very
hard time coming up with a business plan
that could deliver 35 to 40% return on
investment today and and that's one of
the reasons why I've been critical of
micr Finance it's not that it's a bad
idea it's simply that we expect a lot of
some of the poorest people on the planet
in terms of the return on the investment
that is placed in them and and one of
the things that's most missing is really
the opportunity to help them grow as
entrepreneurs and invest in their
ability to learn management and their
ability to run businesses and in my mind
one of the best things we can do is not
just invest in the Ultra poor but find
people who are new students coming out
of school with management degrees and
help them think through business plans
and help them think about how to execute
and there are actually a couple
organizations out there that work on
that endeavor is one of the
organizations working mainly in ltin
America that works with real
entrepreneurs to help them build their
management expertise and their ability
to Market so that they can create more
jobs now that's not micro Finance that's
really investing in entrepreneurs and
and I would really make a distinction
between the two because one is an
approach for helping people who might
already be wealthy get wealthier but
employ a lot more people and another is
figuring out ways to help the poorest of
the poor I think we've got to do both
but we've got to recognize that there
are certainly shortcomings that micro
Finance doesn't currently
address Kaa is certainly an example of
an organization that has masterfully
used the power of the internet to
connect people who are interested in
entrepreneurs and interested in micro
finance and and giving them the
opportunity to actually track that
progress so I mean on that front that's
a that's an Innovative uh extraordinary
breakthrough and of course the the
charge on that Capital tends to be
substantially less than the traditional
micro Finance institutions so I I find
it very refreshing on that front now if
you actually take a look at the project
that people are undertaking they tend
not to be opportunities that are going
to generate dozens and dozens of jobs
they tend to be relatively small
entrepreneurial initiatives which again
might create some employment or some
additional employment for half a dozen
people but will help the immediate
recipient uh come out of extreme poverty
or move from uh poverty towards middle
income um and sometimes what that means
is they can actually invest in friends
businesses they have money to pay for
health care or to put their kids through
school these are all social goods that
are serving ly uh necessary and
warranted and demanded today and and we
do need to understand better how to get
micro Finance out to everyone who can
make use of it but we can't point to
micro Finance as the ultimate solution
even with Kaa and the internet and
everything else to the problems of uh
General underdevelopment and a general
lack of Business Development in the
poorest countries on
Earth
